data.title: Buffer fixes
data.body: Reopened https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/3376

data.title: Fix VertexBuffer.SetData bug introduced in #3356
data.body:
... and add more `SetData` / `GetData` tests to tease out XNA behaviour surrounding `startIndex` / `elementCount` / `vertexStride` parameters.

Fixes the bug introduced in #3356.

Hopefully these tests go some way towards making it clear how these parameters interact. As I understand it, `vertexStride` controls the padding left between source data elements when they are copied to the vertex buffer. It must be `>= sizeof(T)`.

In my opinion, that means it's a somewhat poor choice of name, because if you're passing in a `byte[]`, the value you would choose for `vertexStride` (probably `1`) doesn't really have anything to do with vertex stride. But that's for another time.

I'm sorry for introducing this bug; I'll try to do more testing next time. If you spot anything amiss in this PR, let me know and I'll fix it ASAP.

**IMPORTANT**: @tomspilman , if you want the tests to actually run under XNA, you'll need to change the `RunOneFrame` calls to `Game.Run()`, as per our previous discussion. (I'm not sure why you don't want to use `Game.Run()`, since it has the same effect of running one frame and then exiting. In XNA, `RunOneFrame` seems to assume that the game has already been initialized, which MonoGame does at the start of `RunOneFrame`, but XNA (apparently) doesn't. So it might be non-trivial to get it working in the XNA tests. But that's a separate issue.)

data.title: Implement IntermediateSerializer.Serialize
data.body:
and supporting code, including `IntermediateWriter` and `ReflectiveSerializer.Serialize`.

Related to #2621.

I made some changes to the existing XML test files, for two reasons:
- To make them round-trippable, and
- To remove namespace alias usage from most test files, except for the one specifically related to namespaces

The code should be mostly okay, but `IntermediateSerializer.WriteNamespaces` could do with some cleaning up. That method was the most complicated to write out of all this; it took me a while to figure out XNA's behaviour.

On the bright side, I've ended up with a number of test cases dealing with nested namespaces, ambiguous namespaces, and nested ambiguous namespaces, so it shouldn't be too hard to go in and do some internal refactoring on that `WriteNamespaces` method, without too much risk of breaking anything.

data.title: [Linux] Cannot compile project templetes for MonoDevelop5
data.body:
Hey all,
When trying to install the project templates for Monodevelop 5 (Arch Linux), neither compiling the template project or dragging and dropping the addin folder (as per the instructions) succeeds. After following the directions in https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/ProjectTemplates/MonoDevelop/readme.rtf, MonoDevelop doesn't recognize that there is an addin there. After compiling the project at https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/ProjectTemplates/MonoDevelop/MonoDevelop.MonoGame/MonoDevelop.MonoGame.sln, which succeeds, then running `mdtool setup pack MonoDevelop.MonoGame.dll`, the output is as follows:

```
[user@BEN-PC-ARCH Debug]$ mdtool setup pack MonoDevelop.MonoGame.dll
MonoDevelop Add-in Setup Utility
Creating package MonoDevelop.MonoGame_3.0.0.mpack
FATAL ERROR [2015-01-08 20:17:42Z]: System.IO.DirectoryNotFoundException: Could not find a part of the path "/home/user/workspace/Monogame2015-01-07/ProjectTemplates/MonoDevelop/MonoDevelop.MonoGame/MonoDevelop.MonoGame/bin/Linux/Debug/assemblies/WindowsGL/MonoGame.Framework.dll".
    at System.IO.FileStream..ctor (System.String path, FileMode mode, FileAccess access, FileShare share, Int32 bufferSize, Boolean anonymous, FileOptions options) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
    at System.IO.FileStream..ctor (System.String path, FileMode mode, FileAccess access, FileShare share) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
    at (wrapper remoting-invoke-with-check) System.IO.FileStream:.ctor (string,System.IO.FileMode,System.IO.FileAccess,System.IO.FileShare)
    at System.IO.File.OpenRead (System.String path) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
    at Mono.Addins.Setup.SetupService.BuildPackageInternal (IProgressStatus monitor, System.String targetDirectory, System.String filePath) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
    at Mono.Addins.Setup.SetupService.BuildPackage (IProgressStatus statusMonitor, System.String targetDirectory, System.String[] filePaths) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 

    at Mono.Addins.Setup.SetupTool.BuildPackage (System.String[] args) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
    at Mono.Addins.Setup.SetupTool.RunCommand (System.String cmd, System.String[] parms) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
    at Mono.Addins.Setup.SetupTool.Run (System.String[] args) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
    at MonoDevelopProcessHost.RunSetup (System.String[] args) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
    at MonoDevelopProcessHost.Main (System.String[] args) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
```

data.title: Ability to choose DirectX with OpenAL
data.body:
I have noticed that SharpDX.XAudio is not working with default installation of windows7
Because it bundled DXAudio that slightly lower version of API than expected for SharpDX.XAudio.
This will eventually be solved through installing the newest version of DirectX but I would like to support as many as possible client OSes without installing latest/least prerequisites.

Thus I decided to try out it with OpenAL.

But DirectX / OpenAL not viable without source code modification because two of services (DX Graphics, DX Audio) were coupled in references of ProtoBuild templates and #if DirectX predefined constants.

Except that, I was happy that I can use it with zero deployment packages in windows.

data.title: Allow MGCB and Pipeline Tool to use simple wildcard patterns
data.body:
This is a suggestion for MGCB and the Pipeline Tool to allow content to be built using simple wildcard patterns with only the *, **, and ? characters as used with [MSBuild](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms171453.aspx#BKMK_Wildcards)

I found the way I had to manage files and their options to be a bit cumbersome in the pipeline tool. This is not something one does often, but I think things could be made easier for many people if they could just set up their build settings based on patterns rather than requiring a normal file path. A simple example:

```
/importer:AnimationImporter
/processor:SpecialAnimationProcessor
/build:Content/**/*_S.rani

/importer:AnimationImporter
/processor:PassThroughProcessor
/build:Content/**/*.rani

/copy:Content/**/*.rdec

/importer:TextureImporter
/processor:TextureProcessor
/processorParam:ColorKeyColor=255,0,255,255
/processorParam:ColorKeyEnabled=True
/processorParam:GenerateMipmaps=False
/processorParam:PremultiplyAlpha=True
/processorParam:ResizeToPowerOfTwo=False
/processorParam:TextureFormat=Color
/build:Content/**/*.png
```

This could be presented in the GUI as a special type of item, named as the pattern, that can only be added under the root but is otherwise configured like any other file.

Combining this with a post-build event in visual studio means that content can be added to and built from visual studio without needing to work with a separate build tool GUI in most cases.

data.title: Check Importer and Processor DLL timestamps when deciding whether content needs rebuild
data.body:
Fixes the issue, mentioned in #3138, where updating a `ContentImporter` or `ContentProcessor` used for a content item, didn't force a rebuild of that content item.

I have followed the implementation suggested by @tomspilman [here](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/3138#issuecomment-68819320).

data.title: 2MGFX is hard coded to 64 bits.
data.body:
Running on 32 bit WIndows 7 got;
2MGFX.exe is not compatible with the version of Windows you're running. Check your computer's system information to see whether you need a x86 (32-bit) or x64 (64-bit) version of the pro
gram, and then contact the software publisher.

Looking at the code it seems MojoShader.cs is hardcoded with
const string mojoshader_dll = "libmojoshader_64.dll";

I can build a 32 bit version by adding libmojoshader_32.dll to the project and changing the hardcoded line above and then changing the build target to "Any CPU"

Would need to check the sizeof a UINT to determine which dll to load at runtime and probably update protobuild files to update the project details for a proper solution.

data.title: Mouse position bug under High DPI on Windows
data.body:
My "FPS camera" code, that constantly resets the mouse position to the centre of the window, worked in XNA but doesn't (quite) work in MonoGame. It _sometimes_ works, but other times, if you leave the mouse stationary, it still thinks the mouse is moving by 1 pixel in the X or Y direction.

I've tracked the problem down to DPI scaling. If I set my DPI scaling to 100%, there's no problem. But with 150% scaling, there seems to be a problem with mouse position getting rounded. I haven't looked into it yet, but I guess that somewhere between setting the mouse position and retrieving it, there's a float getting rounded to an int, or something, which means MonoGame constantly thinks that the mouse has moved by a little bit, even if it hasn't.

I'll work on a pull request for this, but I wanted to raise this issue first in case anyone else has experienced this issue. Do any MonoGame developers have DPI scaling enabled on their monitors?

data.title: Add PlaneTest file to XNA test project
data.body: (Fortunately, the new `Plane.Transform` methods seem to match XNA!)

data.title: Implement vertexStride in VertexBuffer.SetData for DirectX platform.
data.body:
This code roughly mirrors the equivalent path in `GetData`, although it is only used when `vertexStride != elementSize`, so it doesn't affect existing usage. An alternative implementation (which I actually tried first), which avoids the need for a staging buffer, would call `UpdateSubresource` once for each element, but I guess that would be very slow for large arrays.

Note that this only implements the `vertexStride` parameter for non-dynamic `VertexBuffer`s (which is actually harder than it would be for dynamic `VertexBuffer`s, since you wouldn't need the staging buffer for a dynamic `VertexBuffer`).

I changed `Game.RunOneFrame()` to `Game.Run()` for these tests, because `Game.RunOneFrame()` doesn't seem to call `Draw()` when running tests in XNA, so the tests gave false positives. If this is really the case (I'd be happy to be wrong!), then we should update other tests to match, or figure out why `Game.RunOneFrame()` isn't calling `Draw()`.

When I try to build I get an error that PrimitiveType does not exist in the namespace "OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL".  This error occurs on line 18 of file GraphicsDevice.OpenGL.cs on the linux build.  Any help would be appreciated. I hope that I am posting this in the correct spot and that I didn't miss anything obvious. Thanks for your time.

data.title: Fix bug when building effects using ContentProcessorContext.BuildAndLoadAsset
data.body:
Fixes #3349.

As discussed in #3350, this is a better fix for the root issue, which is that `ShaderInfo.OutputFilePath` should only be set when building to disk. `BuildAndLoadAsset` does the build in-memory, so `OutputFilePath` isn't set.

data.title: SongCollection should not be mutable
Textures should always be assigned to device, even if they are null
data.body:
I'm not sure if I'm right about this, which is why I'm creating an issue, not a pull request. If it is indeed a bug, then I can create a pull request.

It seems to me that this line is wrong:
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/Effect/EffectPass.cs#L118

I think we should remove the null check, and always set the texture, even if it is null.

For example, if the previously bound texture is a TextureCube (well, Texture2D array, in Direct3D 11 terminology), and the new texture is a Texture2D, but it just happens to be null, then it's still necessary to set that texture slot to null, otherwise Direct3D will complain that the currently bound texture has the wrong dimension for the current shader. (I have this exact situation, which is how I found this.)

data.title: Possible fix for PipelineProcessorContext.BuildAndLoadAsset bug
data.body:
I don't know if this is the correct fix - changing `ResolveOutputFilepath` to `internal` makes me uncomfortable. But more generally, it seems to me (without much knowledge of this code) that `BuildAsset` and `BuildAndLoadAsset` could/should share more code than they are currently sharing.

I'm happy to rework this, if you can give me some pointers on a better way to fix it.

In any case, this fixes the issue I raised in #3349, so I'm now able to build dynamically generated effects. Yay!
